metadata.case_name: Managers of Teok Tea Estate and Dalim Tea Estate v. Labourers and B. L. Sen, Deputy Commissioner, Sibsagar

facts.text: Prior to fixation of minimum wages, labourers engaged in plucking tea leaves paid basic wages of As. 8/- per day for male labourers for plucking 16 seers of green leaves and As. 6/- per day for female labourers for plucking 12 seers of green leaves, calculated at rate of 6 ps. per seer.
If labourers plucked larger quantities, paid extra wages at rate of 6 ps. per seer in excess of 16 seers and 12 seers respectively.

On March 11, 1952, Government of Assam issued notification No. GLR. 352/51/56 fixing minimum wages consisting of basic wages and dearness allowance effective from March 30, 1952, for employees in tea plantations: adult male basic As.12/- + DA As.6/- total 1/21 p.d., adult female basic As.11/- + DA As.5/- total 1/4 p.d. in rest of Assam; exclusive of concessions; existing tasks and hours of work to continue until further orders.
Notification No. GLR. 44/51 dated April 16, 1952 introduced Minimum Wages Rules, Rule 24: normal working day 9 hours for adult, max 48 hours/week.
Notification No. GLR. 352/51 dated May 12, 1952 clarified that 'may' in March 11 notification has force of 'shall'; existing tasks and hours of work shall continue until further orders.
After fixation, managers continued paying at 6 ps. per seer but refused extra payment unless exceeded 24 seers (male) and 22 seers (female), maintaining old standard.

Labourers contended entitled to basic wages As.12/- (male) and As.11/- (female) for existing task of 16/12 seers + extra at 6 ps./seer beyond that; difference of As.4/- (male) and As.5/- (female) per day claimed.
Labourers filed applications under s.20 Minimum Wages Act before Deputy Commissioner Sibsagar for directions to pay difference from March 30, 1952.

Deputy Commissioner entertained applications, held maintainable if less than min wages paid; found existing task 16/12 seers proven by evidence of Hazira Moharers; ordered payment of basic As.12/- for 16 seers male, As.11/- for 12 seers female + extra 6 ps./seer beyond.
Managers filed applications under Art.226 Constitution in Assam High Court (Civil Rules 147/148 of 1952); High Court dismissed on July 7, 1953, granted certificates under Art.133(1)(c).

legal_issues.text: Whether the notification dated March 11, 1952 fixed a minimum time rate irrespective of existing work-load or task, or minimum wages related to existing task of 16/12 seers with extra at 6 ps./seer beyond.

Whether the claims of labourers for extra wages beyond basic for existing task arise out of payment of less than minimum rates of wages under s.20 Minimum Wages Act, conferring jurisdiction on Deputy Commissioner.

petitioner_arguments.text: Notification fixed minimum time rate under s.3(2)(a); basic wages payable regardless of out-turn; no extra for excess over 16/12 seers; no prior fixed task.
Basic wages of As.12/-/As.11/- paid; claim for extra not 'payment of less than minimum rates' under s.20(1); involves complicated facts/law requiring evidence, beyond s.20 authority's jurisdiction.
Continuance of tasks only to prevent employers increasing workload to offset wage increase.

respondent_arguments.text: Existing task 16/12 seers continued per notification; basic wages fixed for that task + extra at 6 ps./seer beyond; non-payment of extra until 24/22 seers is payment less than minimum.

court_reasoning.text: Existing task of 16/12 seers proven by evidence and recognized in notification; basic wages related to that task, not pure time rate; notification intended to increase basic from As.8/6 to 12/11 while maintaining task and extra payment practice.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Direction that existing tasks shall continue shows basic wages linked to workload; appellants' view gives no advantage to labourers.

court_reasoning.text: Does not decide jurisdiction under s.20 as both DC and HC concurrently found for respondents on merits, which SC endorses; matters pending since 1952; no failure of justice in Art.226 proceedings; certiorari discretionary.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Concurrent findings on merits; special reasons not to interfere.

holdings.text: Notification fixed minimum wage for time work related to existing task of 16 seers (male)/12 seers (female); entitled to basic As.12/-/As.11/- for that + extra 6 ps./seer beyond.
Declines to interfere with DC orders upholding labourers' claims despite jurisdiction arguments.

precedents_cited.relevance: Proceedings by way of certiorari are discretionary; High Court could refuse writ if no failure of justice.

statutes_cited.name: Minimum Wages Act, 1948 (Act XI of 1948)
statutes_cited.relevance: Fixation of minimum wages (time rate/piece/guaranteed); claims for less than minimum wages; authority to hear and direct payment.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the appeals, upholding the Deputy Commissioner's orders and High Court's dismissal of Art.226 petitions; confirmed labourers entitled to basic minimum wages for existing task of 16/12 seers plus extra at 6 ps. per seer beyond.
outcome.relief_granted: Labourers' claims upheld; managers directed to pay as per DC order.

key_quotes.text: "the basic wages mentioned in the Schedule were related to the existing workload or task and as. 12/- for the male labourers and as. 11/- for the female labourers were fixed in regard to the existing work-load or task of 16 seers of tea leaves to be plucked by the male labourers and 12 seers of tea leaves to be plucked by the female labourers."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on interpretation of notification linking wages to task.

key_quotes.text: "what was fixed by the notification was not merely a minimum time rate irrespective of the existing work-load or task which used to be performed by the labourers- but was a minimum wage which, though fixed for time work, was necessarily related to the work-load or task then being performed by these labourers"
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "we should decline to interfere... having regard to the merits which have been concurrently found in favour of the respondents both by the Deputy Commissioner, Sibsagar, and the High Court"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Reason for not deciding jurisdiction and upholding orders.
